description:
Human echovirus 1 (EV-1) is a member of the Enterovirus genus within the Picornaviridae family. It is a non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that primarily infects humans.

EV-1 is classified as a member of the Enterovirus A species and is one of the many enteroviruses that can cause a range of clinical manifestations in humans, including mild respiratory illnesses, gastrointestinal symptoms, and rarely, more severe neurological complications.

The virus primarily transmits through the fecal-oral route or respiratory droplets, and it can survive in the environment for extended periods. After entering the host, EV-1 replicates in the gastrointestinal tract and may subsequently disseminate to other tissues, leading to systemic infection.

Diagnosis of EV-1 infection typically involves molecular techniques, such as reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), which can detect the viral genetic material in clinical samples. Treatment for EV-1 infection is generally supportive, as there are no specific antiviral therapies currently approved.

Continued research on the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and potential therapeutic interventions for EV-1 and other enteroviruses is essential to better understand and manage these ubiquitous human pathogens.
